narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to write Film Analysis papers. How to watch a film while thinking of the elements that were used and which were not  and what the reasons are for these decisions made by the director.

I really gained a deep understanding of the history and impact that martial arts films had. It created a rich cinematic landscape that had a lot of nuances to explore. I also learned how to analyze films, an area of study I was previously unfamiliar with.
I learned a lot about the history of martial arts film and the different elements that make up the genre. Also, I learned a lot about the cultural context behind the genre.

I really learned a lot about East Asian Films and dived deeper into a culture that I did not know about until now. Professor Gerow really teaches this class beautifuly, weaving between different countries and genres as cinema evolves over time in East Asia.

If anything, this class exposed me to so many amazing martial arts films that I didn't even know existed and am really glad I got the opportunity to watch. The East Asian martial arts genre has so much more nuance and depth than what meets the eye. The class focuses a lot on themes in martial arts films like sexuality, honor, masculinity, etc. I also learned how to write a film analysis paper for the midterm and final. As a non-film major, I enjoyed learning about how to analyze films and also learning about different filming techniques when it comes to sound, lighting and camera angles.
Knowledge about the history of martial arts cinema, genre studies, and how to write film analysis.
This course helped me understand why martial arts films are famous internationally and gave me a strong foundation to analyze media that I consume.

I have gained a deeper understanding of East Asian martial arts film and film studies in general. I've never previously taken a film class, and this is great for anyone who is remotely interested in learning more about film.
Basic film analyses and history of the East Asian martial arts genre

i developed an understanding of the themes of gender, nationalism, race, foreignness, and other themes present in Chinese wuxia and modern kungu fu films, Japanese jidaigeki historical dramas, and Korean film.
I learned a lot about different East Asian cultures as well as their filmmaking techniques and styles.

I learned about how martial arts in cinema differs based on the culture and the time period. I learned about different styles of filming martial arts. I learned about martial arts tropes in film. I learned to question if a film is a martial arts movie or a just movie that contains some martial arts.

I gained knowledge of various genres of East Asian martial arts film genres, mostly from China and Japan, of films from the early 20th century to present. I was able to analyze martial arts films in regards to its genre and other martial arts films.
Learned a whole lot about martial arts, film, gender, cinematography, and different cultures!

Coming in I had no background in film analysis, but this class introduced not only in-depth visual analysis for film but also more higher-level issues that provide background, context, and further grounds for analysis specific to East Asian martial arts cinema. As a survey course, I was exposed to many key works in the corpus of martial arts cinema and the various historical and cultural developments that affected this overarching genre as it evolved in the many different places they were produced in. This class is not just a survey of film, but also an examination of several evolving cultural dialogues.

knowledge about various east asian martial arts films including wuxia and jidaigeki. Also learned more about film analysis and looked at the social implications of films such as masculinity/femininity in Bruce Lee's character and the female knight errant.
I developed a new found appreciation for Martial Arts films and the culture that comes from it. I also learned how to critique and analyze films on a fundamental level.
I was exposed to a wide range of knowledge surrounding East Asian Martial Arts films and their intersection with other topics such as gender, race, sexuality, and ethnic/national identity.
A solid understanding of Hong Kong history and its relative film history. The traditional forms of martial arts film. A deep understanding of themes and narratives within the genre of film.
I learned how to analyze film scenes and techniques. I also learned a lot about the historical context in which many martial arts films were produced.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The biggest strength of the course would have to be how engaging the live virtual lectures are Professor Gerow is AMAZING!! A weakness would be having weeks where we would have to finish an entire novel + additional discussion/written assignment.

I really enjoyed the breakout sessions that we had often during the lecture. It broke up the monotony of lectures and allowed for ideas and concepts to be discussed. I did find the two movies a bit much however as we were only able to ever discuss one during the section. I loved watching so many movies but I did feel the sheer number of movies made it difficult to really dissect them in section.

I wouldnt say there were any real weaknesses, but I think there are ways it couldve been more interesting. I think the in-class surveys were a nice touch and the overall structure of the class was good.
Class was amazing, really loved it! Take it if you get the chance!

Strengths: you get to watch cool martial arts movies as your assignments. Weaknesses: the course is not very structured. Besides a midterm paper and a final paper, there isn't much in-between besides watching the films. It was fun watching the movies, but I feel like watching them didn't actually help me with writing my papers. I also ended up not watching a few of the movies, and it didn't really affect my ability to attend classes or engage in discussion sections. As a non-film major, I also would have liked to learn more about actual filming techniques and styles instead of focusing so much on themes like sexuality. Going into the class, I also expected to learn more about the origins and backgrounds of different styles of martial arts, but we didn't really get into that much.

Strengths: A VERY knowledgeable professor, a fun curriculum, small class size for a lecture course 

Weaknesses: Sections could use more structure. The level of engagement really depends on your TF and the participation of your fellow students. Also, this class has more movies to watch each week (2-3) than a typical Yale film class. It was fun over quarantine when I was happy to watch movies at home, but keep in mind its a bigger time commitment.

The progression of the films was brilliant. Professor Gerow put a ton of thought to curating the list of movies and ensuring that each week's movies related to the next. The workload was very  heavy at times in that we were expected to read a full novel between lectures and also assigned two movies to watch.  I think that the course would've benefited from diving deeper into a few assigned movies and readings rather than attempting to cover all of them.

The lectures were very short and there was a lot of material to cover. It always seemed like there wasn't enough time to go over anything in depth. If the classes were longer in duration, it would give more opportunities for discussion and questions.
The lectures were informative and entertaining, and the films were really good!
This course was amazing! It was so much fun and so interesting, I am not sure that there are any weaknesses.

This was a very interesting class. The lectures were very insightful and we got to watch a lot of cool and fun movies. Some movies were slow and confusing but they are important to martial arts history.

Professor Gerow's lessons, covering each film we watched, provided very useful insights into the film and allowed me to learn how to analyze martial arts films, both within the film and connecting the film to external topics. Throughout each lesson we would review clips from either the film being discussed or clips from other films that helped us to understand the film being discussed and also to have a refresher on the film. However, if you do not have a particular interest in martial arts film beyond a general appreciation for movies like Kill Bill or Kung Fu Panda, it may be a bit hard to stay engaged with some of the films covered in class.
Great class! In-person screenings on big screens would be great (but not an option in this COVID environment, unfortunately)

A great strength of this course was the flexibility of its final, which encouraged student creativity. 
This course would be improved if it included the film Rush Hour.

This a very fun class with an interesting topic. It can be tough at times to watch all the films on your own, but I imagine this is always better when the course is taught in person. The professor did a good job at keeping lectures engaging but it would also be more helpful if lectures were recorded because it was difficult to take notes at times because of the speed he lectured at/ whenever individual wifi went out.

The movie catalog for this course was really good, and every film offered something different to talk about in discussion sections. The in class lectures where we analyze clips from other films also offered in sight from the readings so we could apply it to the film. The only problem with all of this great content is that sometimes it makes it hard to get all of the readings and all of the films watched and read before each session. Since I'm a freshman still adjusting to life at Yale, it made it a bit difficult to keep up with the content. However, we covered a lot of the content from the readings in lecture so I didn't feel like I was behind not anything.
Loved this course. No weaknesses.

The variety of martial arts films that we watch over the course of the semester is really interesting. The assigned readings are also very interesting and help us understand where a lot of common martial arts literature tropes come from. Sometimes, the readings can be a bit long, especially when we have to read entire books.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that overall the structure worked out very well. The breakout rooms that I mentioned before were an asset to keeping students engaged and present during hour-long lectures. I also wish that we could have had a few more watch parties. I had trouble keeping to the right time in the Buddha's Palm watch party but I did really enjoy the spur of the moment comments and conversations that happened.
This class was amazing, he tried his best to put all the films on Canvas to watch and the course was really exciting.

The virtual polls given throughout class were a lot of fun, and the in-class discussions were also a great way for me to engage with other students. But sometimes the lectures were a bit dry. I also felt like there was not much motivation for me to watch some of the films that I wasn't interested in seeing. Perhaps if there were some guidelines or questions to consider before watching each of the films, I would be more engaged. A lot of times, I didn't really know what I was supposed to be paying attention to in the films. A more structured curriculum and an explanation of what each unit is about might have helped.
I think this class adapted very well to the challenges of covid.
Breakout rooms were an excellent way to discuss scenes/ideas during lecture.
I think this course handled the Covid-19 pandemic as best as it possibly could.
Everything seemed to work well based on the limits of COVID-19.

Virtual classes were generally pretty engaging with the clips we were asked to watch and the breakout rooms we were put in. Discussion section was less so; it was mostly just discussion with a powerpoint and over Zoom that became somewhat harder to stay focused in.

Asynchronous film screenings that we could refer back to later (uploaded through Canvas course reserves/other links) were immensely helpful, especially in managing our time during this past chaotic semester.
Virtual engagement worked very well for this class, especially with the viewings of films and their discussions.

Lectures were engaging, breakout rooms were helpful, and discussion sections were lively, but it would have been extra helpful if lectures were recorded because at times my wifi would go out and kick me from the room for a minute or two and I would miss something important.

Since this course had a strong importance of discussing the content from class, we held zoom discussion sections every week, which all went really well. The discussions were always well organized and went smoothly, except for a few technology hiccups here and there.

The professor did a great job of utilizing the media library during lectures. We were able to watch videos and discuss them without the buffering on zoom. Overall, the course was well adapted for remote learning due to the emphasis on individual screenings.

Generally, the live lectures and discussion sections worked pretty smoothly. Sometimes, the audio would cut out or distort due to connection issues, but those moments were usually brief. I also like the asynchronous lectures as I am able to access their recordings for reference.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most definitely! If you like martial arts films (anywhere between Kung Fu Panda to Ashes of Time Redux), then this is the perfect course for you!

I would definitely recommend this class to future students with a passing interest in film or East Asian popular culture. It was a really fun and informative class that allowed me to explore film and East Asian culture and its greater effects on the wider world in ways that I really enjoyed. The fact that we began from the advent of film and watched black and white films up until films from the twenty-first century allowed for a wide range of exploration within the genres we talked about.
Yes, I think you get a newfound appreciation of other cultures and their entertainment especially.

Definitely take this class if you love to learn more about martial arts and the way they are portrayed in cinema. If you are passionate about the topic or just want to dive deeper and learn more about your culture, this is the class for you!
If you like martial arts movies and are looking for a relatively low workload humanities course, then you won't be disappointed.

If you are interested in film studies, martial arts films, or just want a fun elective, this is a great class. The curriculum is really unique and covers a lot of fan-favorite martial art films while also doing a good job of introducing the class to the history of the genre. Also, if you are an East Asian Studies major or study anything related to East Asia, this is a great class to take because it is a fun way to fulfill major requirements. 

 Also, we watched and discussed Kung Fu Panda, which is a reason in itself to take the class.
Yes!
Yes! I highly recommend this course if you are interested in learning more about film!
Yes! The films are great and gives you a better perspective on global cinema

Yes! If you can definitely take this course. It was at all times interesting and exciting. The films were so much fun to watch and were so entertaining. The discussions were always thoughtful and intriguing.
Yes. This class was fun, and I got to watch many great films.

I would recommend this course to anyone only if this class is taught in-person. I had a hard time staying engaged with the material but only because of the virtual format of classes. Otherwise, the material is actually quite interesting, Professor Gerow and the TF's teach it very well, and watching these films in person with other people would definitely be a fun part of the experience. However, for an online class, I struggled to stay engaged, and given that I don't have a particularly strong interest in martial arts film beyond a general appreciation it was hard for me to keep up.
Yes! Very interesting, I got to watch a lot of movies from cultures across the world. I learned much more than I expected, there really is a lot of depth to these films.

100% recommend. Professor Gerow really knows and appreciates this side of cinema, and the course is built such that you'll walk away with much more than you had going in no matter what your prior experience with film studies or East Asian MA cinema. Although the movie screenings can take up a lot of time (2-3 films a week), they're all interesting and enjoyable films in one way or another.
One of the most interesting courses at Yale. Would definitely recommend.
I would recommend this course to students interested in cinema, as this class covers a lot of ground in East Asian martial arts films.
Yes, one of the best Film classes especially if you enjoy martial films.

Yes, I would definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more about East Asian Culture, Martial Arts Films, or just wants a fun and interesting class in general. I came in to this class interested in learning more about Martial Arts films because I love to watch anime, which sometimes is also based on Martial arts. I never took a film class before this one, and through time, I fit right in as we also bring up the fundamentals of film analysis, so you don't have to worry about not knowing about film analysis.
Absolutely. Engaging and fascinating study on martial arts film.

I would highly recommend this course to students who are interested in martial arts film or even just film. I think the course provides a lot of interesting insight into international film industries and their histories, as well as how the martial arts genre grew in popularity in the west.
